subject: BoJ meeting minutes for March 8th-9th meeting states that BoJ should maintain easy policy as inflation target still a distance,
content:
Says:
- Most members agreed that momentum towards hitting price goal is being maintained.
- Most members saw exports have been on an increasing trend due to firm growth overseas. 

 

Link to minutes release: https://www.boj.or.jp/en/mopo/mpmsche_minu/minu_2018/g180309.pdf

subject: PREVIEW: BoJ minutes from March 8th-9th meeting due at 0050BST/1850CDT/0750HKT
content:
The BoJ are to release the minutes from the January meeting, where the central bank kept monetary policy unchanged as expected, with NIRP held at -0.10% and the 10yr yield target maintained at around 0%, while the policy decision on YCC was made by 8-1 vote with Kataoka the sole dissenter again.

At the meeting, the BoJ commented that Japan’s economy is moderately expanding and that its assessment is unchanged, while board member and regular dovish dissenter Kataoka repeated that BoJ should buy JGBs so yields on 10yr or longer drop further and that BoJ should clarify it will ease further if domestic factors delay reaching price target. The Summary of Opinions for that meeting stated it is appropriate to pursue powerful monetary easing with persistence under the current guideline, while there was also the opinion that with the inflation rate increasing towards target and the potential growth rate rising going forward, the effects of monetary easing measures will be enhanced.

The policy decision failed to impact markets as expectations were unanimous for the central bank to keep policy unchanged, while the statement also didn’t contain anything surprising. This is seen as likely to be the same for today’s release as there has also been a more recent policy announcement in April.

subject: US National Security Advisor Bolton says US President Trump and Kim Jong Un are to meet in Singapore mid-next month
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN AND JAPANESE STOCK NEWS: Westpac earnings, WTI crude rose 1.9%, Japan returns from long weekend; South Korea is closed for holiday
content:
AUSTRALIA

ANZ (ANZ AT)
- Co. announced its plans to improve financial planning service including removal of sales incentives and will also compensate around 9000 clients which were given inappropriate advice. (Newswires)

Orica (ORI AT)
- Co. H1 net excl. material items fell 36.7% to AUD 123.6mln, Cons. Revenue rose 3.9% to AUD 2.5bln. (Newswires)

Sirtex Medical (SRX AT)
- Varian Medical scheme meeting was postponed following an indicative proposal from CDH Investments. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT)
- Co. H1 cash earnings rose 6% Y/Y to AUD 4.25bln, H1 net interest income AUD 8.30bln vs. Prev. AUD 7.69bln. (Newswires)
 

Wesfarmers (WES AT)
- Bapcor is reportedly interested in Wesfarmers' Kmart Tyre & Auto unit. (The Australian)

Other News
- Australian Treasurer Morrison said ahead of tomorrow’s budget release that voters shouldn't expect a mammoth tax reduction and that he is committed to returning Australia back into a surplus as soon and possible. (Newswires)

Energy
- WTI crude rose 1.9%.

 

JAPAN

Nissan (7201 JT)
- Co. is to exit the European diesel-powered vehicle market, according to sources. (Nikkei)
- Co. April China sales rose 18.9% Y/Y to 125.2k units. (Newswires)

Previously reported stories during Japan’s market closure:

Fast Retailing (9983 JT)
- Co. same-store sales rose 10% Y/Y. (Newswires)

Toyota (7203 JT)
- Co. April China sales rose 9% Y/Y to 117.9k units. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Samsung Biologics (207940 KS)
- FSS accounting oversight panel will conduct first meeting next week related to Co.’s alleged violation of accounting regulations. (Newswires)

Westpac (WBC AT) H1 cash earnings rose 6% Y/Y to AUD 4.25bln, H1 net interest income AUD 8.30bln vs. Prev. AUD 7.69bln
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China proposed to the US it would increase US goods imports and lower tariffs on products including cars as a part of the bilateral negotiations, according to sources. In related news, there were also comments from a White House official that US President Trump is said to decide next steps on China after US delegation briefs on the visit. (Newswires)


UK/EU

EU and UK are said to have a list of topics for talks about the future relationship which include financial services, energy, customs and security, while there were also reports that a backup plan to impose border checks on trade between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK has been drafted by Senior Civil Servants. (Newswires)

EU is said to be considering settling the row over US metal levies with quotas, while there were also reports that the EU are open to a 'limited' US trade deal according to a top official. (Newswires)

Moody’s affirmed France at Aa2; outlook revised to positive from stable. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Saudi Arabia is maneuvering to push oil prices up to at least USD 80 a barrel this year, in a shift from policy of stabilising the market. (WSJ)

Iran Deputy Oil Minister Zamaninia said Iran thinks oil output cut agreement will be extended into next year and that prices at USD 60-65/bbl is suitable. (Newswires)

US Baker Hughes Total Rig Count (27 Apr) 1032 (Prev. 1021). (Newswires)


US

Fed's Dudley (Voter, Neutral) Said economic outlook looks pretty good; made progress on inflation, while he added that inflation being slightly higher than 2% is not an issue. (Newswires)

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Hawk) said wage growth is on an upward trend but not picking up fast and that wage growth figures are moderate as are inflation figures, while he also does not see a rapid increase in inflation coming. (Newswires)

Fed's Bostic (Voter, Dovish) said he still expects three hikes this year and could see 2 to 4 hikes depending on data. (Newswires)

Fed's Kaplan (Non-Voter, Neutral) said everything he sees tells him there's a little more wage pressure and that best estimate of neutral rate is 2.50%-2.75%, while Fed's Kaplan also stated that the Fed should continue gradually removing accommodation. (Newswires)

Data Recap
US Non-Farm Payrolls (Apr) 164k vs. Exp. 192k (Prev. 103k, Rev. 135k); 2-month net revision +30k. (Newswires)
US Unemployment Rate (Apr) 3.90% vs. Exp. 4.00% (Prev. 4.10%)
US Average Earnings YY (Apr) 2.6% vs. Exp. 2.70% (Prev. 2.70% Rev. 2.6%)


MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures traded with little action before Wall St open where an initial spike lower was seen as the S&P 500 opened below the 200DMA of 2615 to intraday lows of 2612 before bouncing back and rallying throughout the trading session. The DJIA was lifted by Apple after Warren Buffett said he’d bought a further 75mln shares, taking the stock to its highest level of all time. : SPX +1.3% at 2663, NDX +1.9% at 6769, DJI +1.4% at 24263.

US yields shifted higher after the Nonfarm Payrolls report, to close the session little changed on the day. The equity surge helped push treasuries lower and the curve saw some flattening with the 2-year yield up over 1.5bps. The pull back also came as markets position for next week’s monster supply, as the Treasury is set to issue USD 73bln in 3-, 10- and 30-year paper next week. US 10yr T-Notes futures settle 0.5 ticks higher at 119-22.
